comments: It appears that a(n) <= prime(n)^2-1, where prime(n) = A000040(n) is the n-th prime; see A035095 for a related conjecture. If correct, this implies A006530(a(n)+1)=prime(n), which in turn implies that there are no duplicated values in the sequence.
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{p = Prime@ n}, r = p - 1; While[ !PrimeQ@ r, r += p]; r]; Array[f, 50] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 20 2014 *)
prog: (PARI) a(n) = {prn = prime(n); p = 2; while(p % prn != prn - 1, p = nextprime(p+1)); p;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Aug 04 2013(Haskell)a032448 n = head [q | q <- a000040_list, let p = a000040 n,                      q `mod` p == p - 1]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 08 2013
author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 25 2003
